115600 S0021-9517(24)00313-0 10.1016/j.jcat.2024.115600 Fig. 1 EPMA analysis showing elemental distribution of Al, Ag, Pd and Sn for Pd0.4Ag0.05Sn-6eq (7), prepared with a high Ag content (resulting in a surface enrichment of Ag), low hydrazine concentration and 0.05 wt% Sn, which forms an eggshell. Fig. 2 XPS spectra of the Pd 3d, Ag 3d and Sn 3d showing the expected binding energy regions. Fig. 3 (A) Fitted Sn3d 5/2 spectra; (B) Pd3d spectra; (C) Chart of Sn composition. (D) Quantification chart of major components. 1: As received sample, 2: Post HPGC reaction, and 3: exposure to atmosphere. Fig. 4 AC-STEM images showing d-spacings for IR-1 (top row left), IR-2 (top row middle) and Pd0.2Ag-H2 (10) (top row right), together with measured d-spacing of Pd0.4Ag0.05Sn-6eq (7) after pretreatment in hydrogen with the corresponding AC-STEM image (underneath). Also shown is an EDS image showing Pd, Ag and Sn elemental dispersions for Pd0.4Ag0.05Sn-6eq (7), together with a bar chart showing the differences in d-spacings for catalysts IR-1, Pd0.4Ag0.05Sn-6eq (7) and Pd0.4Ag0.05Sn-6eq (7) after pretreatment in hydrogen. Fig. 5 Acetylene conversion as a function of temperature (top) and selectivity towards ethylene as a function of acetylene conversion for IR-1, IR-2, and Pd0.4Ag-24eq (3), Pd0.2Ag0.05Sn-24eq (5), Pd0.2Ag0.025Ru-24eq (11) and Pd0.2Ag0.025Au-24eq (12) (bottom). All experiments were conducted with 10 mL catalyst under a flow of 1 % acetylene, 1.1 % hydrogen, balance ethylene at a pressure of 17 barg and GHSV of 6400 h−1. Conversion was increased by increasing the temperature from 30 to 80 ˚C over 10 ˚C intervals. Fig. 6 Acetylene conversion as a function of temperature (top) and selectivity towards ethylene as a function of acetylene conversion for IR-1 and Pd0.2Ag-6eq (4) and Pd0.2Ag-H2 (10) (bottom). Fig. 7 Acetylene conversion as a function of temperature (top) and selectivity towards ethylene as a function of acetylene conversion for IR-1 and catalysts 6–9 (bottom). Fig. 8 Acetylene conversion as a function of temperature for IR-1, IR-2, and Pd0.4Ag0.05Sn-6eq (7) with 1.1 % H2 and 1.4 % H2 inlets. Fig. 9 Selectivity towards ethylene as a function of conversion for IR-1, IR-2, and Pd0.4Ag0.05Sn-6eq (7) with 1.1 % H2 and 1.4 % H2 inlets. Fig. 10 Acetylene conversion as a function of time together with the temperature required to maintain ca. 70 % conversion (top) and selectivity towards ethylene as a function of time online (bottom) for IR-1, IR-2, and Pd0.4Ag0.05Sn-6eq (7). Fig. 11 C2H2 and C2H4 adsorption geometries on ([111]) alloy surfaces of PdAg3 and Pd3Ag as well as their Sn doped analogues [Pd3Ag_Sn([111]) and PdAg3_Sn([111])]. The different binding sites available on a ([111]) surface are highlighted in clean Pd3Ag([111]) (A = atop, B = bridge, C = hollow). Table 1 Composition of catalysts evaluated for the selective hydrogenation in the presence of ethylene. Additive wt.% refers to amount of Sn, Ru or Au. Graphical abstract PdAg/Al2O3 catalysts were prepared using a simple and scalable preparation method. A systematic approach established a preparation-performance relationship which revealed that the Pd:Ag ratio and Pd reduction method affects the overall performance for the selective hydrogenation of acetylene to ethylene under industrially relevant tail-end reaction conditions. The addition of Sn improved selectivity with the optimum system achieving 97% selectivity towards ethylene, outperforming two industrial references. Density functional theory (DFT) simulations and electron microscopy analysis revealed that Sn integrates into the Pd lattice and increases the energy barrier for ethylene adsorption. This work demonstrates that Sn can be used to tailor catalyst performance for industrially relevant PdAg/Al2O3 catalysts. Keywords Industrial Catalysis Acetylene Tail-end Selective hydrogenation Palladium Silver Tin Abbreviations AC-STEM Aberration corrected scanning transmission electron microscopy BET Brunauer–Emmett–Teller DFT Density functional theory DRIFTS Diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy EPMA Electron probe microanalysis FID Flame ionization detector GC Gas chromatography GHSV Gas hourly space velocity HPGC High pressure gas cell ICP-OES Inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy TCD Thermal conductivity detector TEM Transmission electron microscopy XPS X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy Data availability The data that has been used is confidential. 1 Introduction Ethylene is a critical chemical building block and is used in the manufacture of polyethylene, ethylene oxide, ethylene dichloride and ethylbenzene [1,2]. Over 250 million tons of ethylene feedstock is produced annually by steam cracking naphtha and ethane [3]. Whilst other routes including oxidative coupling of methane [4] and methanol to olefins [5] are currently the subject of extensive research effort, it is expected that petroleum-based technologies will continue to be the primary source of ethylene for the following decade [6]. However, despite the efficiency of the steam cracking process, this route also produces acetylene as a by-product. This must be selectively removed via hydrogenation, as it is a poison for the Zeigler-Natta ethylene polymerisation catalyst [7]. The reaction conditions for the selective hydrogenation of acetylene on an industrial scale are typically defined by the plant configuration; the C2 fraction can be isolated from the steam cracking process in either a front-end or tail-end unit [8]. In the front-end configuration, reaction feed is taken directly from the conversion section of the ethylene plant and the composition of the gas mix typically contains a large excess of hydrogen with respect to acetylene, together with other olefinic compounds and CO [9]. Tail-end units are situated further downstream, enabling the addition of stoichiometric hydrogen into the C2-rich feed produced from the de-ethanizer, to target high ethylene yield [9]. Whilst many active species have been reported including cationic Ni(II) and NiZn alloys [10,11], metallic Cu and Cu carbide [12], metallic Fe [13] and metal-free systems based on reduced graphene oxides [14,15], Pd-based catalysts are the most widely used and have been shown to be highly active for the hydrogenation of acetylene. However, the poor selectivity of unmodified monometallic systems leads to reduced ethylene yield and short lifetimes which limits their use on an industrial scale [16]. Despite this, several examples exist in the literature of monometallic systems harnessing different innovative means of decorating the active Pd site to achieve higher selectivities. Zhang et al. demonstrated that immobilisation of the ionic liquid 1-butyl-3-methylimidazolium chloride onto an Al2O3 support enhanced the selectivity of Pd catalysts on the basis that the limited solubility of hydrogen at the ionic liquid-catalyst interface creates a hydrogen deficient phase, thus preventing over-hydrogenation of the ethylene [17]. Utilising Diffuse Reflectance Infrared Fourier Transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS), Anderson et al. reported that the incorporation of phosphorus into the Pd lattice disrupts reactive contiguous Pd sites, which have the propensity to further hydrogenate ethylene. The resultant TiO2-supported PdP2 and Pd3P catalysts achieved up to 84 % selectivity towards ethylene at 100 % acetylene conversion [18]. Given that further hydrogenation of ethylene generates ethane, which due to the absence of the C = C pi bond, results in devaluation of the C2 product mix, it is critical that catalysts for industrial use are highly selective and tolerable to the reaction conditions. To this end, alternative organic-free strategies that promote selective hydrogenation of acetylene include the use of bimetallic and/or trimetallic active phases. The state-of-the-art industrial catalysts primarily consist of PdAg bimetallic systems [19]. The incorporation of Ag into the active phase has been shown to improve selectivity and lifetime. For example, Hardacre et al. reported that the addition of Ag facilitates the formation of a surface PdAg alloy; this results in an inherent downshift in the d-band centre which leads to the benefit of both the selectivity and longevity of the catalyst. DFT computational analysis confirmed this modification increases the reaction barriers for further hydrogenation and undesired coupling reactions [20]. Other catalyst examples include controlled deposition of Pd onto parent Cu catalysts [21], introduction of Mn additives [22] and PdAu nanoparticles embedded in colloidal templated silica [23]. Given that the hydrogenation of acetylene is highly exothermic − at least for typical adiabatic reactor use on an industrial scale- a robust catalyst system with a tuneable activity profile would be desired to manage the reactor temperature [24]. On this basis, the scope of the following work is to identify an optimum system that exhibits both high selectivity towards ethylene and a modular activity profile, enabling efficient acetylene clean-up under industrially relevant conditions whilst simultaneously preventing high temperature rises throughout the catalyst bed which negatively impacts both lifetime and selectivity. To this end, two industrial PdAg/Al2O3 reference samples (IR-1 and IR-2) were used as benchmarks for the selective hydrogenation of acetylene to ethylene. IR-1 is a Johnson Matthey proprietary catalyst which, while possessing a high activity is unsuitable for use on large scale industrial tail-end units. IR-2 is an alternative catalyst more representative of the desired industrial performance. This catalyst is widely used in industry as despite achieving only modest selectivity, its activity profile is more amenable to full scale operation. Several changes to the formulation and preparation method for IR-1 were studied to determine whether it was possible to improve the performance. This is discussed in Section 3. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Catalyst preparation IR-2 was prepared using the published preparation procedure [25]. The alumina support used for all preparations was obtained from Axens (Product code: 515C, 2–4 mm spheres, alumina phase = theta-alpha, BET surface area = 38.1 m2/g). IR-1, IR-2 and the series of development samples were prepared by co-impregnation of the alumina support with an aqueous solution of Pd(NO3)2 (obtained as a 15.08 wt% solution in demineralised water, Johnson Matthey, product code: 174070) and AgNO3 (Thermo Scientific, 99.9+%) using the incipient wetness method. Nitrates were chosen as Na and Cl free precursors. The Pd concentration was fixed at 250 ppm. The concentration of all other components is shown in Table 1 . Ru was incorporated using a mixed solution of Ru, Pd and Ag nitrates (Ru(NO3)3NO obtained as a 13.87 wt% solution in demineralised water, Johnson Matthey, product code: 194004). For catalysts IR-1, 3–9, 11 and 12, after impregnation and ageing for 20 min, the catalysts were then reduced in an aqueous solution of hydrazine (35 wt% aqueous solution, Merck) in a 24:1 M excess (unless otherwise stated) with respect to the total metal content. The catalyst was then washed with deionised water and dried overnight at 105 ˚C. Catalysts IR-2 and 10 were both reduced with hydrogen, rather than hydrazine. After impregnation and drying, the catalysts were placed in an atmosphere-controlled oven. The oven was purged with nitrogen for 45 min, and the temperature was then increased to 320˚C using a 5˚C/min ramp rate. Once the temperature set point had been achieved, the catalysts were allowed to dwell under a constant flow (100 L/h) of 2 % H2/N2 for 4 h. The catalysts were then cooled to room temperature under a nitrogen atmosphere before purging with air. Due to incompatibility of the precursors with the mixed metal nitrate solution, gold and tin-containing catalysts were prepared using a second impregnation step in which the reduced PdAg catalyst was impregnated with an aqueous solution of either H[AuCl4] (obtained as a 39.66 wt% solution in demineralised water, Johnson Matthey, product code: 070022) or Na2[Sn(OH)6]·3H2O (Merck, 95 %). For gold-containing catalysts, the catalyst was then re-reduced with hydrazine in a 24:1 M excess. A sample of each catalyst was analysed by ICP-OES to confirm the target composition was achieved (ESI Table S1). The compositions of the catalysts are shown in Table 1. The nomenclature applied to the development catalysts reflects both their composition and the reduction method applied during catalyst synthesis (all Pd loadings are fixed at 0.025 wt%). For example, Pd0.2Ag0.05Sn-6eq implies a composition of 0.025 wt% Pd, 0.2 wt% Ag, 0.05 wt% Sn/Al2O3 reduced using an aqueous solution of 6 M equivalents of hydrazine. 2.2 Characterisation of catalysts Chemisorption: The palladium surface areas were measured using a MicromeriticsTM 2480 HTP Chemisorb analyser. The samples were reduced under optimal conditions and cooled to analysis temperature whereby carbon monoxide (CO) was dosed onto the sample over a selected range of pressures (100–450 mmHg). The chemisorbing CO was allowed to stabilise at each pressure point prior to the instrument measuring the uptake. Pressure may then be plotted by uptake to give a chemisorption isotherm. This isotherm illustrates the ‘total’ quantity of gas uptake by the sample, providing a measure of both physisorbed and chemisorbed species. To determine solely the chemisorbed CO, the sample was evacuated further to remove the physisorbed species. The isotherm was then measured once more; the difference showing the amount of CO physisorbed which allowed the chemisorbed component to then be calculated. At the end of the analysis the sample was discharged, and the reduced weight of the sample was used in the metal area calculations. EPMA analysis was undertaken using a Jeol JXA-8500F electron probe microanalyzer with five wavelength dispersive spectrometers and one SDD (silicon drift diode) EDX detector. The samples were embedded in resin, grinded, polished, and then carbon coated before scanning. Quantitative maps were run by first acquiring standards in Probe for EPMA, acquiring mapping data for the actual sample and then converting the intensity maps to quantitative maps using CalcImage. The data was then plotted using Surfer 10. XPS data were collected using a ThermoScientificTM ESCALABTM Xi+ spectrometer using Al Ka radiation (1486.6 eV) with a hemispherical analyser. The resulting spectra were analysed using the ThermoScientific Avantage software with the binding energy scales corrected to the Al2p (74.5 eV) signals for alumina. For ex situ treatments, the samples were placed into cups of aluminium foil and clipped to a sample block designed for an ex-situ high pressure gas cell (HPGC). XP data were collected using a ThermoScientific ESCALAB Xi+ spectrometer using Al Ka radiation (1486.6 eV) with a hemispherical analyser. XP data were collected in the analysis chamber with a base pressure of 2 × 10-10 mbar. The samples were transferred to the preparation chamber (base pressure of 2 × 10-7 mbar) where they were placed into the HPGC, without breaking vacuum, and sealed. The samples were then exposed to 5 bar 5 % H2/Ar2 for 90 min at 140 °C in static mode. The samples were cooled under vacuum and then transferred back to the analysis chamber. After the post treatment measurements, the samples were taken out of the UHV chamber and exposed to atmosphere for 1 h before remeasuring. ICP-OES analysis was carried out using an Agilent 5800/5900 ICP-OES; samples were digested with HCl using an Anton Paar multiwave microwave. Samples were prepared for scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) by scraping from the top layers of the sample and crushing the resultant powder between two glass slides. The powder was dusted on to a perforated carbon copper TEM grid. STEM images were acquired using a JEOL 2800 S/TEM field emission gun microscope at 200 kV. Aberration corrected images were obtained using a JEOL ARM 200 CFE probe corrected STEM operated at 200 kV located in I14, Harwell. Both instruments had two Energy Dispersive X-ray detectors. Nanoparticle size distributions were obtained from measurements using a bespoke application on typically 50 + particles assuming a spherical shape. 2.3 Catalyst testing procedure The as-prepared catalysts were then evaluated for the selective hydrogenation of acetylene in the presence of ethylene. The gas phase reaction was conducted in two parallel oil-jacketed fixed bed reactors (5/8-inch diameter tube). Temperature was controlled with circulating JULABO heaters. Each reactor was charged with 10 mL of catalyst over three discreet beds, separated by silicon carbide (120 grit). The catalyst bed was secured with glass wool and 3 mm glass beads. Before introduction of the reaction feed, the catalyst was reduced in a flow of hydrogen (5 barg) at 140˚C over a two-hour period. After reduction, the reactors were cooled to 30 ˚C and purged with nitrogen at a flow rate of 100 L/h until the system had equilibrated and only nitrogen was flowing. In a typical experiment, reaction conditions were based on industrially relevant conditions; a flow of 1 % acetylene, 1.1 % hydrogen, balance ethylene was applied at a pressure of 17 barg and a GHSV of 6400 h−1. Reaction temperatures were varied between 30–80 ˚C, allowing the system to stabilise for 15 min, before holding at a specified temperature for 60 min. The test rig was heated using a circulating oil jacket heated using a JULABO oil bath. As a result, any heat generated was quickly removed from the system and no exotherm was observed, preserving isothermal conditions. During the 60-min hold, four GC samples were analysed, and an average outlet composition was taken. Reaction and product mixtures were analysed via in-line GC analysis fitted with flame ionisation detector (hydrocarbons) and thermal conductivity detector (permanent gasses). GC calibrations were conducted using standard gas mixtures obtained from ST gasses. During dwell periods, outlet gases were analysed by inline GC, alternating between reactor 1, reactor 2 and inlet via a switchable Valco valve. The GC method and equilibration procedure were completed within approximately 15 min. Conversions and selectivities were calculated using inlet/outlet mol % as follows: (1) Conversion = ( ( a c e t y l e n e i n l e t - a c e t y l e n e o u t l e t / a c e t y l e n e i n l e t ) x 100 (2) EthyleneSelectivity = 100 - ( ( e t h a n e o u t l e t - e t h a n e i n l e t ) / a c e t y l e n e i n l e t - a c e t y l e n e o u t l e t ) ) x 100 2.4 DFT computational details Density functional theory (DFT) calculations were carried out using the grid-based projector augmented wave code (GPAW) [26]. Bulk lattice parameters for face centred cubic (fcc) Pd (a = 3.98 Å) and Ag (a = 4.20 Å) were obtained using the planewave cut-off of 1100 eV, Monkhorst-Pack k-point mesh of 8x8x8 [27]. The C2H2, C2H4, and H2 were calculated in boxes of 14 Å × 15 Å × 16 Å, at the gamma point only. The Pd, Ag, Pd rich Pd3Ag1, and Ag rich Pd1Ag3 [[111]] surfaces were modelled with four atomic layers and a vacuum gap of 12 Å. These slab models are designated as Pd or Ag for the metallic and Pd3Ag or PdAg3 for the bimetallic alloy systems. During the simulation, the two top layers of the slab and adsorbed species were allowed to relax. PAW potentials were used to describe the core electrons, and the electron–electron interaction was described using the BEEF-vdW [28]. The geometry optimisations were carried out using the BFGS algorithm as implemented in atomistic simulation environment (ASE) [29] with a grid-spacing of 0.18 Å and a 4x4x1 Monkhorst-Pack grid of k points. A smearing width of 0.1 eV was used at the Fermi level and all energies were extrapolated to T = 0 K. The calculations were considered converged when the residual forces were smaller than 0.05 eV Å−1. A similar approach has been reported in literature by Illas et. al. [30]. The impact of Sn was simulated by changing one of the atoms in the metallic or bimetallic slabs to Sn. These Sn doped models are labelled as Pd_Sn, Ag_Sn Pd3Ag_Sn or PdAg3_Sn. There are three possible adsorption sites on fcc [[111]] metal surface as shown in Fig. 10. These are atop (a), bridge (b) and interstitial hollow (3) sites. The reactivity of these surface models to C2H2 and C2H4 was then investigated. The adsorption energies (ΔEads) were calculated using equation (3) and the most stable geometry’s ΔEads reported. (3) Δ E ads = E surf + a d s o r b a t e - ( E adsorbate + E surf ) Where Esurf, Esurf+adsorbate and Eadsorbat are the total DFT energies of the [[111]] surface model, the [[111]] surfaces with the adsorbate, and gas-phase C2H2 or C2H4 respectively. 3 Results The aim of this work was to optimise the performance of IR-1 and produce a catalyst with a more robust activity profile that exhibits improved selectivity towards ethylene under tail-end reaction conditions. To this end, several modifications to IR-1 (which is typically highly selective at lower temperatures but thought to be too active in comparison with IR-2) were investigated which resulted in the preparation of a series of 10 development catalysts shown in Table 1. Firstly, a series of formulation changes were employed; a lower Pd:Ag ratio was proposed given that DFT analysis indicated acetylene hydrogenation is not accessible on Ag-only sites (vide infra). A possible secondary effect of this strategy is the obstruction of accessible Pd sites with additional Ag, or dilution of monometallic Pd ensembles. Secondly, alternative catalytically active components ruthenium and gold were investigated to determine whether it is possible to promote selective adsorption of acetylene through electronic modification of the d-band of the active site and facilitate improved selectivity. Au is well known for its ability to selectively coordinate acetylene, especially in cationic form [31], and recently, PdRu bimetallic catalysts have been shown to increase selectivity for the partial reduction of alkynes due to a reduction in hydrogen storage capacity compared to monometallic Pd catalysts [32]. Further modifications included investigating how the catalyst preparation method affects the final catalyst, together with the incorporation of dopants into the formulation. To this end, Sn was selected as it is a low-cost dopant with an existing precedent as a selectivity modifier in Pd-based selective hydrogenation catalysts. For example, addition of Sn to Pd/C catalysts increased the selectivity towards ethylene compared with the unmodified catalyst; DFT calculations suggested that Sn promotes an alternative acetylene adsorption mechanism [33]. 3.1 Catalyst characterisation 3.1.1 EPMA (Electron probe micro Analysis) The location of the metallic components within the alumina pellets was investigated by EPMA (full details and images in the ESI). Pd was found at the outer surface of the alumina spheres, in an ‘eggshell’ distribution, which is indicative of a strong interaction of the Pd salt and the Al2O3 surface causing the metal to precipitate. Surface enrichment with Pd through eggshell formation is desirable due to diffusion limitations and high gas space velocities [34]. In comparison to IR-1, IR-2 had a thicker Pd eggshell distribution, indicative of a lower surface Pd content. Pd0.2Ag-H2 (10), which was reduced in hydrogen appears to have the highest surface Pd content. In contrast to Pd, for samples with Pd:Ag ratios of 1:8 IR-1, Pd0.2Ag-6eq (4), Pd0.2Ag0.05Sn-6eq (5), Pd0.2Ag-H2 (10), Pd0.2Ag0.025Ru-24eq (11) and Pd0.2Ag0.025Au-24eq (12)), Ag penetrated deeper within the pores of the support. However, increasing the Ag content (i.e. a Pd:Ag ratio of 1:16) decreased the diffusivity of the Ag component, resulting in significant surface enrichment with Ag (Pd0.4Ag-24eq (3), Pd0.4Ag-6eq (6), Pd0.4Ag0.05Sn-6eq (7), Pd0.4Ag0.025Sn-6eq (8) and Pd0.4Ag0.1Sn-6eq (9)). This effect could be promoted as the pH of the impregnating solution will be reduced due the increase in concentration of nitrate ions; this would mean that precipitation on the support occurs more readily. For Sn-containing samples Pd0.4Ag-6eq (6), Pd0.4Ag0.05Sn-6eq (7), Pd0.4Ag0.025Sn-6eq (8) and Pd0.4Ag0.1Sn-6eq (9), the Sn was found to preferentially deposit on the surface of the spheres and increasing the Sn concentration increased the thickness of the eggshell.Fig. 1 . 3.1.2 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis XPS was used to determine the oxidation state of the metallic components for IR-1, IR-2, and catalysts 3–12, revealing that all samples contained mixtures of PdII and Pd0. Due to the low Pd loading, it was not possible to accurately quantify the Pd speciation. Accurate deconvolution of the Ag3d peak was also not possible due to the small binding energy separation between different species. However, the binding energies of 368–369 eV are consistent with those reported in the literature for metallic Ag and Ag2O mixtures [35]. For all samples, the binding energy of the Pd3d signal was found to be in the ranges of 336–337 eV, which is consistent with reported literature values and suggests the dominant Pd species in the Pd speciation mixture was Pd(II) [36]. Given that particle sizes for all catalysts are commensurate, final state effects are ruled out in this instance. For Sn-containing catalysts, Sn was found to exist in the oxidic state as SnIV [37]. No evidence of Sn was found for Pd0.4Ag-6eq (6) confirming that observable Sn peaks are not due to any contaminants. The spectra in Fig. 2 show the expected binding energies for Pd, Ag and Sn. In agreement with EPMA, surface atomic ratios as determined by XPS (full details in the ESI, Tables S2 and S3) revealed a much higher Pd/Ag ratio for IR-1 compared with IR-2 (1.6 vs 0.2) suggesting that the surface of IR-1 is more Pd rich whereas IR-2 is Ag rich. The Pd/Ag ratios for catalysts 3–12 varied between 0.4–1.6. The highest Pd/Ag ratios were found for IR-1 and Pd0.2Ag-H2 (10), also in agreement with EPMA. For Pd0.4Ag0.05Sn-6eq (7), Pd0.4Ag0.025Sn-6eq (8) and Pd0.4Ag0.1Sn-6eq (9), the Pd/Sn ratios were in the range of 0.2–0.4 suggesting an excess of Sn compared to Pd at the surface. 3.2 XPS analysis after ex situ hydrogen treatment. In an attempt to identify the composition of the active species (post-reduction), a sample of the catalyst was analysed using ex situ XPS analysis Fig. 3 . After analysing a fresh sample of Pd0.4Ag0.05Sn-6eq (7), the sample was transferred to a connected high pressure gas cell (HPGC). The sample was then exposed to hydrogen at a pressure of 5 barg and a temperature of 140 °C for 90 min to simulate the reduction step performed in the reactor prior to introduction of the feed gas. Without exposure to the atmosphere, the sample was then transferred back to the analysis chamber and reanalysed. After this, the sample was exposed to air, aged for one hour and further reanalysed. Fitting of the Sn3d 5/2 spectra for the fresh catalyst revealed three distinct signals − one at 486.2 eV assigned to Sn(II), one at 486.6 eV assigned to Sn(IV), and one at ∼ 487 eV which is assigned to an unknown high oxidation state Sn species. The fresh catalyst contained predominantly Sn(IV). After reaction in the HPGC most of the Sn at the surface reduced to Sn(II). Exposure to air resulted in all Sn(II) at the surface being oxidised to Sn(IV). This result demonstrates that standard XPS is not able to accurately characterise the surface of the active species, which contains Sn(II). The fresh catalyst had two species of Pd present; Pd(II) at 337 eV and Pd(0) at 335.5 eV. After treatment in hydrogen at 140 °C, the signal at 337 eV decreased while a new, lower binding energy Pd(0) species appeared. This species had a binding energy of 334.5 eV which could be attributed to a palladium alloy. After exposure to air, the Pd(II) signal increased slightly whilst the low binding energy palladium signal disappeared. The low signal intensity along with the asymmetry of the Pd(0) signals is indicative of a high degree of uncertainty with fitting these spectra. Plot D shows the quantification of Al combined with the metals of interest. This shows that there is no major change in composition after exposure to the reactor, and therefore changes in surface chemistry will be the dominating factor. 3.2.1 TEM analysis An elegant study conducted by Liu et al. used machine learning technology to rationalise the global potential energy surface of Pd-based catalysts, in order to identify the defining catalyst features that promote selective partial hydrogenation of acetylene. One dominant feature was the particle size distribution of the active site, and nanostructure engineering afforded larger particles that increased selectivity towards ethylene [38]. Studying the effect of Pd particle size for the selective hydrogenation of acetylene using SiO2-supported PdNPs, Borodzinski reported that whilst the PdNP diameter had no electronic influence of the adsorption of the reactants, larger particles promote selectivity towards ethylene due to a geometric effect based on the surface sites of crystalline Pd phases [39]. To examine the nanostructure of IR-1, IR-2, and catalysts 3–12, samples were analysed using TEM. TEM analysis confirmed that all samples consisted of well dispersed nanoparticles with only a small variation in size ranges (Table 2 , full details together with images and statistical histograms available in ESI). The largest particles for the PdAg catalysts (excluding the Ru-doped catalyst) i.e., the lowest surface area to volume ratio, were found for IR-2 (6.0 ± 2.2 nm) which reflected the metal surface area results obtained from CO chemisorption (Table 2). Addition of excess Ag (Pd0.4Ag-24eq (3)) and Sn (Pd0.2Ag0.05Sn-24eq (5)) to IR-1 appeared to have negligible effect on the average particle size. The reduction method appeared to show some influence over the kinetics of nanoparticle formation. For example, in comparison to IR-1, reducing the Pd/hydrazine ratio (Pd0.2Ag-6eq (4)) resulted in slightly larger particles. Furthermore, reduction in the presence of hydrogen (i.e., in the absence of hydrazine, Pd0.2Ag-H2 (10)) resulted in smaller particles. The stepwise addition of Au to IR-1 (Pd0.2Ag0.025Au-24eq (12)) may have resulted in deposition of Au on top of Pd sites causing an increase in the average particle size. Aberration corrected STEM (AC-STEM) analysis of selected samples revealed differences in nanoparticle composition. For example, an interatomic spacing (d-spacing) of 2.30 Å was measured for IR-1. Although it was not possible to confirm the composition of this species, the measured spacing lies between that of the lattice parameters for Pd[111] (2.236 Å) and the Ag[111] (2.40 Å) and is therefore attributed to the formation of a PdAg alloy (Fig. 4 ). Particles with larger spacings of 2.40 Å were also found suggesting the presence of isolated Ag [40–42]. This is likely due to the high excess of Ag in the catalyst. However, for IR-2, no evidence of PdAg alloying was found; d-spacings of 2.08 and 2.42 Å were measured which suggests that here the Pd and Ag have not alloyed. Similar d-spacings of 2.40 Å were also found for Pd0.2Ag-H2 (10), which also showed no evidence of PdAg alloying, further confirming the effect of the reduction method. These two samples were the only samples reduced with hydrogen, rather than hydrazine, indicating that hydrazine is required to achieve alloying of Pd and Ag. Under these conditions, it is possible that PdAg alloying could be achieved simply by employing a powerful chemical reducing agent (i.e., hydrazine) that fixes Pd and Ag within an accessible proximity, whereas a wicking mechanism takes place during hydrogen reduction, reducing Pd-Ag contact. Another possible suggestion, although unlikely, is that hydrazine acts as a template by coordinating both Pd and Ag during the reduction step. When employing an aqueous solution of NaBH4 as a powerful, non-chelating chemical reductant for the reduction of metal oxide supported Pd/Ag ions (which is outside of the scope of this work) Zahmakiran et al. found evidence of PdAg alloying, which suggests that templating agents are not required [43]. Indeed, Du et al. proposed that the NaBH4-mediated rapid reduction of Pd and Ag salts enabled Pd and Ag to quickly fuse and form alloys for the electro-oxidation of ethylene glycol [44]. EDS imaging confirmed that for Pd0.4Ag0.05Sn-6eq (7), Pd, Ag and Sn are within proximity (Fig. 4). Evidence of augmentation of the d-spacing in comparison with the non-Sn doped sample was found (2.339 Å for vs 2.30 Å) which suggested integration of Sn into the PdAg lattice. Moreover, a sample after simulating the activation procedure was also examined; an even larger d-spacing of 2.367 Å was observed indicative of further integration of Sn into the crystal lattice. The average particle size of the reduced sample increased by ca. 31 % suggesting a degree of structural rearrangement. However, no significant changes in the macromolecular structure were detected with EPMA (ESI Figure S13). On this basis it is proposed that hydrazine mediated the alloying of Pd and Ag whilst subsequent hydrogen activation enabled alloying with Sn; both modifications are known to facilitate the disruption of contiguous Pd sites. CO chemisorption analysis, which enables quantification of the reactive metal surface area available for catalysis, was conducted for all samples. The differences in particle sizes as determined by TEM for Pd0.2Ag-H2 (10) and Pd0.2Ag0.025Au-24eq (12) were also reflected in the CO chemisorption results as these catalysts had the highest and lowest metal surface areas, respectively. It was also found that although IR-1 has a lower total metal surface area (derived from the CO chemisorption isotherm) in comparison with IR-2, IR-1 has a higher strong metal surface area (probed by evacuating the chamber to remove weakly bound physisorbed CO), indicative of different types of adsorption sites. 3.3 Selective partial hydrogenation of acetylene 3.3.1 Effect of formulation changes The effect of formulation on the conversion of acetylene and selectivity towards ethylene is shown in Fig. 5 , where IR-1 was modified by adding Sn, Ru or Au. Samples IR-1 and IR-2 were used as benchmarks to compare against catalysts 3–12. A temperature range of 30 to 80 ˚C was used for screening catalysts. The oil jacketed system enabled heat from the reaction exotherm to be quickly removed, facilitating an isothermal operation. The system was allowed to stabilise for 15 min before being held at each temperature set point for one hour, allowing four data points to be collected. The conversion was then plotted against selectivity to allow the intrinsic selectivity to be evaluated. A direct comparison of IR-1 and IR-2 confirmed that IR-2 is significantly less active, for example, at 30 °C, the conversion for IR-2 (26 %) was significantly lower than IR-1 (50 %). To examine the effect on the catalyst selectivity, the selectivity towards ethylene was plotted as a function of acetylene conversion (Fig. 5). Compared with IR-1, IR-2 required a temperature increase from 30 to 45 °C to achieve a comparable conversion (47 %). Under these conditions, both catalysts had similar selectivities towards acetylene hydrogenation (94 %). Given that Rahimpour et al. demonstrated that using both experimental and computational methods proved that low temperatures favour oligomerisation of the C2 components, which is a prerequisite to green oil formation and catalyst deactivation [25], this demonstrates the benefits of industrial use of IR-2 compared with IR-1. Catalysts 3–12, which were prepared by modifying the preparation route of IR-1 in an attempt to identify the defining catalyst features that promote selective acetylene hydrogenation and a tuneable activity profile, were then tested under comparable conditions. Increasing the Ag content of IR-1 from 0.2 to 0.4 wt% resulted in a lower Pd/Ag surface ratio and a lower activity as Pd0.4Ag-24 eq (3) achieved only 38 % conversion at 30 ˚C whereas IR-1 achieved 50 % under the same conditions. Near-quantitative conversion was reached at 60 ˚C for Pd0.4Ag-24eq (3) whereas IR-1 reached > 99 % conversion at 50 ˚C. Some minor differences in the selectivity profiles were observed for Pd0.4Ag-24eq (3) in comparison to IR-1; selectivity remained relatively constant at 91–92 % up to 80 % acetylene conversion and decreased to 85 % above 90 % acetylene conversion. The selectivity profile for IR-1 remained stable at 91–94 % up to 90 % acetylene conversion but decreased significantly to 78 % as acetylene conversion increased above 90 %. This effect demonstrates the propensity of PdAg catalysts to catalyse the further hydrogenation of ethylene at elevated temperatures. In keeping with reported PdAg systems, the increased selectivity of Pd0.4Ag-24eq (3) is attributed to the obstruction of active Pd sites with Ag [16,19,20,21]. Modification of IR-1 with Sn (Pd0.2Ag0.05Sn-24eq (5)) resulted in a similar activity profile as shown in Fig. 1. Interestingly, whilst Pd0.2Ag0.05Sn-24eq (5) had the highest selectivity below 90 % conversion (95 % and 94 % selectivity at 75 % and 82 % conversion, respectively), this profile suggested an intrinsic change in the catalyst selectivity profile and warranted further investigation (vide infra). Despite consisting of larger particles, the addition of Au to IR-1 (Pd0.2Ag0.025Au-24eq (12)) conferred an increase in activity, demonstrating the electronic effect of Au. For example, acetylene conversions of 66 and 90 % were achieved at 35 and 40 ˚C, respectively whereas IR-1 achieved 50 and 78 % under the same conditions. This is consistent with the activity of bimetallic PdAu catalysts reported by Johnston and Hutchings for the synthesis of vinyl chloride monomer, in which the combination of Pd and Au led to a highly active catalyst [45]. It has been proposed that in bimetallic PdAu systems, the alkynophilicity of Au promotes selective adsorption of acetylene and the Pd component enables efficient dissociative adsorption of hydrogen resulting in a highly active catalyst [46,47]. Surprisingly, at lower conversions, the selectivity of the two catalysts were similar (93 % at ca. 65 % conversion and 92 % at ca. 79 % conversion). At higher conversions, the selectivity decrease was slightly larger for Pd0.2Ag0.025Au-24eq (12) (88 and 84 % selectivity at 90 and 96 % conversion) compared to IR-1 (91 and 85 % selectivity at 90 and 95 % conversion). However, both catalysts had similar selectivities as the acetylene approached full conversion (80 and 99 % acetylene conversion). The introduction of Ru into the formulation (Pd0.2Ag0.025Ru-24eq (11)) resulted in an intrinsic change in catalyst performance as the conversion was comparatively lower under the same conditions as IR-1. For example, 35 % acetylene conversion was obtained at 30˚C for Pd0.2Ag0.025Ru-24eq (11) compared to 50 % achieved with IR-1. Furthermore, a temperature of ca. 70 ˚C was required to achieve 99 % conversion for Pd0.2Ag0.025Ru-24eq (11) vs ca. 50 ˚C for IR-1. The selectivity of Pd0.2Ag0.025Ru-24eq (11) was markedly lower than that of IR-1, for example, 87 % and 85 % selectivity at ca. 60 and 70 % acetylene conversion respectively, compared with 93 % and 92 % under similar conditions. 3.3.2 Effect of reduction method Several preparation modifications were targeted to generate a more robust activity profile and higher selectivity. For example, it has been shown that the reduction method used for PdAg catalysts can significantly affect both the Pd particle size and thus the overall catalyst performance [48]. In this instance, two simple modifications were made to the preparation. Firstly, for Pd0.2Ag-6eq (4), it was reasoned that that the Pd:hydrazine ratio would impact the kinetics of nanoparticle formation, and thus the Pd:hydrazine molar equivalents were decreased from 1:24 to 1:6. This change also carries secondary logistical benefits given that the decomposition of hydrazine in the presence of Pd results in the formation of ammonia-based species which is hazardous and challenging to handle on a manufacturing scale. Secondly, for Pd0.2Ag-H2 (10), hydrogen reduction was employed as it is practically straightforward, scalable, and clean. The conversion and selectivity data in Fig. 6 show that reducing the equivalents of hydrazine only resulted in a minor decrease in conversion compared to IR-1. The selectivity to ethylene formation was also similar with a small increase in selectivity for Pd0.2Ag-6eq (4) being observed. For example, 97 % selectivity at 45 % acetylene conversion and 94 % selectivity at 50 % conversion was achieved for Pd0.2Ag-6eq (4) and IR-1, respectively. Both catalysts demonstrated a significant drop in selectivity as conversion approached 99 % (82 and 78 % selectivity at 97 % conversion for Pd0.2Ag-6eq (4) and IR-1, respectively). As well as there not being a step change in performance, these data demonstrate that the hydrazine concentration could be reduced to limit emissions and exposure concerns at commercial scale manufacture, whilst giving a modest improvement in catalyst performance. In stark contrast, the activity of the sample reduced with hydrogen was demonstrably lower in comparison to IR-1; only 21 % acetylene conversion was achieved at 30 ˚C with Pd0.2Ag-H2 (10) in comparison to 50 %. The effect of hydrogen reduction is also demonstrated in terms of selectivity as Pd0.2Ag-H2 (10) produced significantly more ethane in comparison to IR-1. The selectivity towards ethylene at 52 and 50 % was 94 and 86 % for IR-1 and Pd0.2Ag-H2 (10), respectively. Given that the samples have the same PdAg surface ratio (1.6:1) and similar particle size distributions, it is likely that the difference in performance is related to the electronic composition of the active site, and the relative distribution of Pd compared to Ag (i.e., alloying as opposed to intimate mixtures as discussed in section 3.1.3). 3.3.3 Combinatory effects To ultimately target a catalyst system that is able to exhibit high selectivity together with a modular activity profile, a combinatory approach was used to prepare a further catalyst sample based on promising results obtained with Pd0.4Ag-24eq (3), Pd0.2Ag-6eq (4) and Pd0.2Ag0.05Sn-24eq (5). To investigate this, a catalyst was prepared based on IR-1 with a higher Ag content/lower Pd:Ag ratio and reduced equivalents of hydrazine in the reduction step. This has been shown to produce a catalyst which has a much more stable activity profile more suited to industrial use. To this catalyst, Sn was added, as the previous experiments have shown that the addition of Sn has shown to impart a significant improvement towards the selectivity to ethylene. Four samples were prepared, each varying the Sn content in order to identify the optimum Pd:Sn ratio. The conversion and selectivity data in Fig. 7 appear to show a direct correlation between Sn content and overall activity as acetylene conversion at 30 ˚C increased from 13 to 22 to 27 % as the Sn content decreased from 0.1 wt% to 0.05 wt% to 0.025 wt% respectively. This result indicates that adsorption and/or hydrogenation of acetylene is not possible on Sn sites, and therefore the Sn content could also be used as an activity modifier to tailor the conversion profile for PdAg catalysts. This further supports the disruptive nature of Sn with regards to contiguous Pd sites. Furthermore, the selectivity enhancement observed with Sn-doped Pd0.2Ag0.05Sn-24eq (5) was also observed with Pd0.4Ag0.05Sn-6eq (7), Pd0.4Ag0.025Sn-6eq (8) and Pd0.4Ag0.1Sn-6eq (9) at 64–65 % acetylene conversion. The selectivity of IR-1 (93 %) also increased to 96 and 97 % for the 0.025 and 0.05 wt% Sn-doped samples respectively. As conversion increased above 90 %, all samples exhibited a decrease in selectivity as ethylene was converted to ethane in the absence of acetylene at higher temperatures. 3.3.4 High hydrogen inlet testing During industrial operation, the acetylene/hydrogen ratio can be manipulated to control catalyst activity and compensate for catalyst deactivation towards end of life. Whilst this operational strategy offers a tuneable approach to achieve the desired conversion profile, high concentrations of hydrogen can lead to significant temperature rises, triggering runaway ethane production. This affect was demonstrated computationally by Gislason et al. who showed that higher atomic hydrogen surface coverage promotes further hydrogenation of ethylene to ethane [49]. To examine how Pd0.4Ag0.05Sn-6eq (7) and the two industrial reference catalysts respond to a hydrogen-rich environment, the hydrogenation concentration was increased from 1.1 to 1.4 %, giving an acetylene/hydrogen ratio of 1:1.4. The data in Fig. 8 show that increasing the hydrogen content resulted in a marked increase in conversion for all three catalysts. At 30˚C, conversion increased from 50 to 79 % for IR-1. Acetylene conversion of Pd0.4Ag0.05Sn-6eq (7) was similar to that of IR-2. At 30˚C, conversion increased from 22 and 23 % to 36 and 46 % for Pd0.4Ag0.05Sn-6eq (7) and IR-2, respectively. Near-complete conversion (ca. 97 %) was achieved at temperatures of 40, 45 and 50 ˚C for IR-1, IR-2, and Pd0.4Ag0.05Sn-6eq (7), respectively. With a hydrogen inlet concentration of 1.4 %, Pd0.4Ag0.05Sn-6eq (7) maintained a high ethylene selectivity, achieving 95 % selectivity as conversion reached 66 % Fig. 9 . After this, selectivity decreased to 83 % at 88 % conversion. A similar performance was obtained with IR-2 (94 % selectivity towards acetylene at 66 % conversion). Selectivity also dropped at higher conversion with IR-2 achieving 88 % selectivity towards acetylene at 87 % conversion. Whilst a high selectivity of 90 % was obtained with IR-1 at 78 % conversion, the data in Fig. 8 further demonstrates the propensity of IR-1 to reach high conversion at low temperatures; this effect, which is synonymous with challenging plant scale operation, is then augmented at higher hydrogen inlet concentration. 3.3.5 Lifetime studies Pd0.4Ag0.05Sn-6eq (7) was subjected to a longevity test to determine whether the high selectivity shown in Fig. 7 could be maintained over long periods. Given that the major catalyst deactivation mechanism is based on green oil formation and subsequent carbon laydown, it is not only important to identify the ideal activity-selectivity relationship, but also to determine how the deactivation rates of the catalysts compare. Typical industrial tail-end processes consist of two, or three consecutive reactor beds. The C2 fraction produced in the de-ethanizer is firstly dosed with hydrogen and is then passed over the lead catalyst bed which aims to convert 70–75 % of the acetylene into ethylene [50]. Therefore, to emulate industrial operation, Pd0.4Ag0.05Sn-6 eq (7) together with IR-1 and IR-2 were operated at a temperature that corresponds to ca. 70 % conversion. The catalysts were held at an appropriate temperature to achieve an initial acetylene conversion of approximately 70 % for a period of 15–20 h. Once conversion dropped, the temperature was increased to maintain approximately 70 % acetylene conversion. This study also allows for the intrinsic selectivity to be probed by operating isothermally and at isoconversion. Isothermal operation was achieved by circulating JULABO oil through the oil jacket to remove any heat generated by the reaction exotherm. Due to the decreasing ethylene selectivity over time for IR-2, the reaction was stopped after 45 h. The conversion profile (Fig. 10 , top chart) shows that after approximately 20 h online, all three catalysts had a similar activity profile. The initial activity of IR-1 and IR-2 decreased significantly over the first 20 h before stabilising. After this time, Pd0.4Ag0.05Sn-6 eq (7) compared favourably with both IR-1 and IR-2; a minor decrease in acetylene conversion from 70 % to 66 and 67 % for Pd0.4Ag0.05Sn-6 eq (7) and IR-1 was observed from 20 to 34 h online. After increasing the temperature at 35 h, acetylene conversion decreased from 73 % to 66 and 68 % for Pd0.4Ag0.05Sn-6 eq (7) and IR-1. The operating temperatures required for achieving ca. 70 % conversion after 20 h for IR-1, IR-2, and Pd0.4Ag0.05Sn-6 eq (7) were 37, 59 and 55 ˚C, respectively, which further highlights the undesirably high activity of IR-1 for use on an industrial scale where due to the exothermic nature of the reaction, temperatures regularly exceed 45 ˚C [50]. The selectivity profile (Fig. 10, bottom chart) shows that Pd0.4Ag0.05Sn-6 eq (7) was consistently more selective than IR-1 and IR-2 throughout the study. All catalysts incurred a minor decrease in selectivity towards ethylene which decreased from 94 to 90 %, 91 to 86 % and 91 to 83 % for Pd0.4Ag0.05Sn-6 eq (7), IR-1 and IR-2, respectively. These observations agree with the conclusions of a comprehensive review of existing catalyst technologies for acetylene hydrogenation produced by Bond and Borodzinski who reported that selectivity typically declines as a function of time due to the deposition of carbonaceous species on the catalyst surface [51]. The authors propose that the build-up of carbonaceous layers limits diffusion of acetylene within the catalyst pore structure, resulting in loss of activity. Moreover, whilst carbonaceous deposits on Pd surfaces generate selective sites for acetylene hydrogenation, analogous carbonaceous sites within the metal oxide support create additional reactive sites via hydrogen spillover. These sites promote further hydrogenation of ethylene to ethane, negatively impacting selectivity. The results for Pd0.4Ag0.05Sn-6 eq (7) compare well with other reported systems. For example, whilst high activities were obtained with nickel supported on nitrogen-doped activated carbon, the selectivity towards ethylene was only 46 % [52] and an overall ethylene yield of 93 % was reported for Pd supported on multi-walled carbon nanotubes [53]. CHNS analysis of the spent samples was conducted to compare the relative amounts of green oil and other undetected carbonaceous species that had formed on the catalyst surface. The results in Table 3 show that IR-1 had the highest concentration of carbon on the spent catalyst and Pd0.4Ag0.05Sn-6 eq (7) had the lowest. Given that IR-2 was operated for a shorter period, a deposition rate was calculated which indicated that IR-2 had the highest rate of carbon formation and Pd0.4Ag0.05Sn-6 eq (7) had the lowest. This result further demonstrates the benefits of the new formulation. 4 Discussion Based on the work presented here, a more robust activity profile together with increased selectivity towards ethylene can be achieved by optimising both the Pd:Ag and Pd:hydrazine ratios, together with the incorporation of Sn. Despite having a similar particle size distribution to IR-1, Pd0.4Ag0.05Sn-6 eq (7) exhibited a significantly different performance profile; to investigate this effect, a computational density functional theory (DFT) study was conducted in an attempt to rationalise the interfacial electronic effect of Pd, Ag and Sn. The adsorption of acetylene and ethylene was modelled using DFT on a series of surfaces both with and without the inclusion of Sn at the active site. 4.1 Computational Analysis: Effect of Ag and Sn on adsorption of acetylene and ethylene. A series of [[111]] surface models were used as a representation of an extended nanoparticle surface to probe the reactivity of C2H2 and C2H4 on Sn-doped alloys of Pd and Ag. The [[111]] facet was chosen as it is dominant surface. As proposed by Studt et al., by introducing a scaling relationship between the adsorption energies of the reactants and intermediates, the reactivity of the catalyst can be rationalised using the relative adsorption energies of C2H2 and C2H4 [11]. Together with monometallic Pd and Ag sites, the bimetallic slab models with elemental compositions of Pd3Ag and PdAg3 were also modelled to reflect bimetallic PdAg sites that are both Pd rich and Ag rich. The adsorption geometries of C2H2, and C2H4 on [[111]] surfaces of Pd, PdAg3, Pd3Ag and Ag are shown in Fig. 11 and the Eads (eV) listed in Table 4 . In the pure Pd system, the hollow site was identified as the most stable adsorption site for the C2H2 which is consistent with other reported findings in literature [54,55]. The introduction of Ag (Pd3Ag and PdAg3) does not change the preferred adsorption site. However, it is notable that Pd dominates the reactivity of the systems especially in the PdAg3 model where there are other possible adsorption sites with only Ag. The reactivity trend with reference to C2H2 in the models is as follows, Pd > Pd3Ag > PdAg3 > Ag. Introduction of Ag as modelled in the Pd3Ag slab reduces reactivity towards C2H2 with a decrease in the ΔEads from −2.06 to −1.82 eV. A further reduction in reactivity is predicted in the Ag rich model, PdAg3, with an even lower ΔEads of −0.62 eV. It has been established in the literature [56] that the stronger the adsorption/binding of C2H2 on the surfaces, the higher the barrier for the desorption, leading to hydrogenation and formation of C2H4. However, if the C2H4 remains strongly adsorbed on the catalyst surface, further hydrogenation may occur resulting in formation of undesired C2H6. To assess the selectivity of the systems, the adsorption of the C2H4 over the surface was also investigated. The C2H4 ΔEads was less favourable compared to that of C2H2 but the trend remains the same where Pd > Pd3Ag > PdAg3 > Ag. This agrees with the experimental data whereby IR-1 achieves higher conversion in comparison with its Ag-enriched counterpart, Pd0.4Ag-24eq (3). The incorporation of Sn as a dopant to the model systems does not change the order of reactivity to either C2H2 or C2H4. However, it diminishes the overall reactivity, hence the ΔEads of both C2H2 and C2H4 are less thermodynamically favourable. In the case of Ag-rich PdAg3, the introduction of Sn increases the ΔEads of C2H2 from −0.61 to −0.37 eV. This is also the case for adsorption of C2H4 on Sn-modified sites, which become even less thermodynamically favourable; this further supports the experimental evidence for Pd0.4Ag0.05Sn-6eq (7) which suggests that intercalation of Sn into the Pd lattice prevents further hydrogenation of C2H4 to C2H6. 5 Conclusions A series of industrially representative Al2O3-supported PdAg-based catalysts were prepared using a simple and scalable method. A systematic investigation of the preparation method, catalyst composition, metal ratio and the inclusion of a third metal was conducted which showed that together the Pd:Ag ratio, Pd reduction method and the nature of the third metal impact the catalyst performance for the selective hydrogenation of acetylene under tail-end conditions. It has been shown that the inclusion of Sn in the catalyst formulation greatly improves the selectivity of the catalyst towards ethylene formation. The optimum system was a Sn-doped PdAg catalyst and a computational study using DFT was used to establish a theoretical chemical basis for the role of Sn, which agreed with experimental results. It is proposed that the role of Sn, which is partially reduced from SnIV to SnII during the in-situ activation, is twofold. Firstly, incorporation of Sn at the active site increases the energy barrier for the adsorption of both acetylene and ethylene, and secondly, given that adsorption does not occur on Sn sites, Sn provides geometric promotion through integration into the Pd and PdAg lattices disrupting contiguous Pd sites (as evidenced by AC-STEM analysis). Varying the Sn content demonstrated that controlled integration of Sn into PdAg catalyst formulations is a tuneable way to tailor the activity and selectivity for the semi hydrogenation of acetylene under industrially relevant conditions. Pd0.4Ag0.05Sn-6eq (7) demonstrated excellent selectivity with time online compared to industrial references. This catalyst also demonstrated a stable activity profile and had a lower rate of carbon formation, making it an ideal candidate for real world use. For this reason, the catalyst has also been patented [57]. This method can be integrated into the design of future catalysts to formulate materials with superior performance, both in terms of activity profiles and improved selectivities compared to current industrial catalysts. coredata.dc:description: PdAg/Al2O3 catalysts were prepared using a simple and scalable preparation method. A systematic approach established a preparation-performance relationship which revealed that the Pd:Ag ratio and Pd reduction method affects the overall performance for the selective hydrogenation of acetylene to ethylene under industrially relevant tail-end reaction conditions. The addition of Sn improved selectivity with the optimum system achieving 97% selectivity towards ethylene, outperforming two industrial references. Density functional theory (DFT) simulations and electron microscopy analysis revealed that Sn integrates into the Pd lattice and increases the energy barrier for ethylene adsorption. This work demonstrates that Sn can be used to tailor catalyst performance for industrially relevant PdAg/Al2O3 catalysts.
